subject: Re: [junit] Paper on Abstract vs. Concrete parameters
msgSnippet: Yes, that rings true with me, and looks like a good analysis.  Thanks for writing that up! Seems to me that the third way here is the one I gravitate
messageBody:
Yes, that rings true with me, and looks like a good analysis. Thanks
for writing that up!

Seems to me that the "third way" here is the one I gravitate towards:
pass the narrowest possible interface into the method in question. In
each case, you could define an interface with two getters and pass
that into the method. Your production code would have "Customer
implements MortalityCriteria" for the first scenario. For the second
case, you could have the "legacy" method cobble together a dynamic
implementation, or the class could contain a private implementation
that it constructs only once to call the new method. The worst
penalty you pay is having big classes like Customer bogged down with a
ton of interfaces, but in my practice that doesn't seem to happen too
often.

FYI, I thought your initial message about the idea was clear too, so I
may not be your target audience. ;)

> paper: www.threeriversinstitute.org/AbstractVsConcreteParameters.html. In
> short, it tries to resolve the apparent contradiction between achieving
> testable code sometimes by making parameters concrete and sometimes by
> making parameters abstract. I'd appreciate feedback, examples, and
